summary: acute respiratory infections are a leading cause of infectious disease-related morbidity, hospitalisation and mortality among children worldwide. most patients with acute respiratory infection are still treated empirically. the aim of the study was to evaluate the risk factors associated with the evolution and outcome of respiratory illnesses in patients under 5 years old. these diseases are responsible for at least 6% of the world's disability and death. it is estimated that there are 33.7 million cases of respiratory infection annually among African children. longitudinal studies suggest that the overall mortality rate among children in developing countries is between 6.6% and 14.1%. the national referral hospital in the third district of the urban municipality of Antananarivo is paid for by the patients. the paediatric and neonatology ward of CENHOSOA has 54 beds and the annual number of children hospitalized for respiratory infection was estimated to be 150. a panel of multiplex real-time RT-PCR was used for the detection of viral pathogens in nasopharyngeal swabs.
